title: South Australian woman found in dense bushland days after disappearance after leaving SOS signal
text:
A woman who went missing in dense bushland on the weekend has been found alive and well.

Deborah Pilgrim, 55, disappeared on Sunday after she went camping in Sedan, northeast of Adelaide, with friends.

She managed to leave an SOS signal on a dirt track, which was discovered by Neil Marriott, a local ex police officer who owned the property the track led to.

Deborah Pilgrim (pictured), 55, disappeared on Sunday after she went camping near Adelaide with friends

He stumbled across the signal as he was checking his CCTV cameras.

Mr Marriot called police late on Tuesday night.

They found Ms Pilgrim at midnight on a neighbouring property, where she had found a fresh supply of water.

'If you keep your cool and you keep walking, you'll eventually come to a road,' Mr Marriot said.

But he confessed the track could have seemed endless to someone who wasn't familiar with the area.

'It's very, very dense mallee scrub,' he told ABC Radio Adelaide.

South Australian police confirmed she was taken to Angaston Hospital for a routine check up after the ordeal.
description: Deborah Pilgrim, 55, disappeared on Sunday after camping in Adelaide with friends.
authors: Brittany Chain For Daily Mail Australia
